prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: H13CN(1-0), HC15N(1-0), and HCN(1-0) in L1527 and L1489
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band 3 observations of main target lines H13CN(1-0), HC15N(1-0) and HCN(1-0) in the two young stellar objects L1527 (IRAS 04368+2557) and L1489 (IRAS 04016+2610). Bonus lines of HN13C(1-0), H15NC(1-0) and a broad-band continuum window can be observed in addition at a reasonable data rate.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
For L1527 (IRAS 04368+2557), the sensitivity requirement is determined by the desired detection of HC15N(1-0) at a S/N ratio of at least 10, as required for imaging. The integrated intensity of H13CN(1-0) is 0.43 Kkm/s from the Onsala 20m telescope (Jorgensen et al. 2004, A&A 416, 603), which corresponds to 5.02 Jy/beam km/s. For a line width of approximately 0.6 km/s (also from Jorgensen et al. 2004), the expected peak line flux is 7.83 Jy/beam (assuming the source is not resolved in the 44'' Onsala beam).
Scaling by conservative (non-fractionated) isotopic ratios of 12C/13C=69 (Wilson 1999, Milam 2005) and 14N/15N=441 (Marty et al. 2011) gives an estimate of 7.83*69/441 = 1.23 Jy/beam for HC15N(1-0). The expected spatial extent for the H13CN and HC15N is about 5'' (from barely resolved HCN(1-0) observations with BIMA, Choi et al. 1999, ApJS 122, 519) and thus a lower limit on the estimated line peak flux is 49 mJy/beam in a 1'' beam. Thus, for a S/N ratio of 10, a sensitivity of 4.9 mJy/beam in 0.6 km/s channels is required. However, if the nitrogen isotopes are fractionated as expected, the peak flux of HC15N will be higher.
For L1489 (IRAS 04016+2610), we use the same approach: H13CN(1-0) is 0.29 Kkm/s = 3.39 Jy/beam km/s (Jorgensen et al. 2004). For a line width of 0.6 km/s (Jorgensen et al. 2004), the expected H13CN(1-0) peak flux is 5.30 Jy/beam. Thus, HC15N(1-0) is expected at 0.83 Jy/beam. This source is more compact than L1527, so for an estimated source size of around 4'' the expected HC15N(1-0) peak flux is 51 mJy/beam in a 1'' beam. Thus, for a S/N ratio of 10 for imaging, a sensitivity of around 5 mJy/beam in 0.6 km/s channels is required for this source as well.
The continuum fluxes were taken from Hogerheijde et al. 1997, ApJ 489, 293 for both sources.

The requested spectral resolution of around 0.12 km/s for the H13CN and HC15N lines allows us get several data points over the line profiles (expected line widths of about 0.6 km/s) and resolve the hyperfine structure in H13CN(1-0), where the components are split by 5-7 km/s. The spectra can be smoothed as required to reach the requested sensitivity. The estimated line widths are taken from Jorgensen et al. (2004, A&A 416, 603).

We aim for a spatial resolution of about 1'', as this corresponds to solar system scales at the distance of Taurus (140 pc). At 1'' resolution, we will obtain several resolution elements across the protostellar envelopes. We do not aim at resolving the disks.
The emission of H13CN(1-0) and HC15N(1-0) is expected to be extended over an area of about 4-5'', whereas the main isotopologue HCN(1-0) is extended by 10-20'' (Choi et al. 1999, ApJS 122, 519). Because HCN is needed to check the 12C/13C ratio, we ask for the largest scale to be that of HCN, namely 20''.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: H13CN(1-0), HC15N(1-0), and HCN(1-0) in L1551 IRS 5 and TMR1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band 3 observations of main target lines H13CN(1-0), HC15N(1-0) and HCN(1-0) in the two young stellar objects L1551 IRS 5 (IRAS 04287+1801) and TMR1 (IRAS 04361+2547). Bonus lines of HN13C(1-0), H15NC(1-0) and a broad-band continuum window can be observed in addition at a reasonable data rate.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
For L1551 IRS 5 (IRAS 04287+1801), H13CN(1-0) was measured at the NRAO 12m telescope by Roberts et al. (2002, A&A 381, 1026) with a line width of 0.62 km/s, and an integrated intensity of 0.114 K km/s. Assuming that the source is unresolved in the 73'' beam, this corresponds to 3.70 Jy km/s /beam or a peak flux of 5.61 Jy/beam. Scaling by conservative (non-fractionated) isotopic ratios of 12C/13C=69 (Wilson 1999, Milam 2005) and 14N/15N=441 (Marty et al. 2011) gives an estimate of 5.61*69/441 = 0.87 Jy/beam for HC15N(1-0). Assuming that the HCN isotopologues have an extent comparable to L1489 of 4'', this gives a peak flux of 54 mJy/beam in a 1'' ALMA beam. For a S/N of 10, as required for imaging, an rms of 5mJy in 0.6 km/s (comparable to the line width) is required. However, if the nitrogen isotopes are fractionated as expected, the peak flux of HC15N will be higher.
For TMR1 (IRAS 04361+2547), H13CN(1-0) was measured at the Onsala 20m telescope by Jorgensen et al. 2004 with an integrated intensity of 0.15 K km/s and a line width of 0.5 km/s. The H13CN peak intensity for a Gaussian line is therefore 0.28 K, which corresponds to 3.44 Jy/beam. Scaling for HC15N(1-0) as above yields 0.60 Jy/beam. This source is even more compact than the other two Class I sources (L1489 and L1551 IRS 5), so for an estimated source size of around 3-3.5'' the expected HC15N(1-0) peak flux is 50-65 mJy/beam in a 1'' beam. Thus, for a S/N ratio of 10 for imaging, a sensitivity of around 4.9 mJy/beam in 0.6 km/s channels is sufficient for this source as well.
The continuum fluxes were taken from Hogerheijde et al. 1997, ApJ 489, 293 for both sources.

The requested spectral resolution of around 0.12 km/s for H13CN and HC15N allows us get several data points over the line profiles (expected line widths of about 0.6 km/s) and resolve the hyperfine structure in H13CN(1-0), where the components are split by 5-7 km/s. The spectra can be smoothed as required to reach the requested sensitivity. The estimated line widths are taken from Jorgensen et al. (2004, A&A 416, 603).

We aim for a spatial resolution of about 1'', as this corresponds to solar system scales at the distance of Taurus (140 pc). At 1'' resolution, we will obtain several resolution elements across the protostellar envelopes. We do not aim at resolving the disks.
By comparison with L1527, the emission of H13CN(1-0) and HC15N(1-0) is expected to be extended over an area of about 4'', whereas the main isotopologue HCN(1-0) is extended by 10-20'' (Choi et al. 1999, ApJS 122, 519). Because HCN is needed to check the 12C/13C ratio, we ask for the largest scale to be that of HCN, namely 20''.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: H13CN(3-2) and HC15N(3-2) in L1527 and L1489
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band 6 observations of main target lines H13CN(3-2), HC15N(3-2) in the two young stellar objects L1527 (IRAS 04368+2557) and L1489 (IRAS 04016+2610). Bonus lines of HN13C(3-2) and a broad-band continuum window can be observed in addition at a reasonable data rate.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The sensitivity requirement is determined by the desired detection of the faintest line HC15N(3-2) at a S/N ratio of at least 10, as required for imaging. Based on H13CN(3-2) to H13CN(1-0) peak flux ratios in the range of 0.82-2.0 from the protostar sample by Jorgensen et al. 2004 (A&A 416, 603), the expected peak flux in the J=3-2 transition should be at least 0.8 times the peak flux of the J=1-0 transition. The estimate for HC15N(1-0) in L1527 is 49 mJy/beam in a 1'' beam, so the expected peak flux for HC15N(3-2) is around 40mJy/beam in a 1'' beam. Thus, for a S/N ratio of 10, a sensitivity of 4 mJy/beam in 0.6 km/s channels is required.
For L1489, we use the same approach: HC15N(1-0) has a peak flux of 51 mJy/beam, so the HC15N(3-2) flux should be at least 0.8*0.51 mJy/beam = 41 mJy/beam. For a S/N ratio of 10, a sensitivity of 4 mJy/beam in 0.6 km/s channels is required as well.
The continuum fluxes were taken from Hogerheijde et al. 1997, ApJ 489, 293 for L1527 and L1489.
The estimated line widths are expected to be similar to the J=1-0 transitions from Jorgensen et al. (2004, A&A 416, 603).

The requested spectral resolution of around 0.04 km/s for the spectral lines allows us resolve the line profiles (expected line widths of about 0.6-1 km/s). The spectra can be smoothed as required to reach the requested sensitivity.

We aim for a spatial resolution of about 1'', as this corresponds to solar system scales at the distance of Taurus (140 pc). At 1'' resolution, we will obtain several resolution elements across the protostellar envelopes. We do not aim at resolving the disks.
HCN(3-2) is expected to be more compact than HCN(1-0), which is extended by 10-20'' in L1527 (Choi et al. 1999, ApJS 122, 519) in barely resolved measurements with BIMA. The isotopologues are usually more compact and thus expected to be extended over an area of about 4-5''. We want to cover scales up to 10'' in case they are more extended than expected.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: H13CN(3-2) and HC15N(3-2) in L1551 IRS 5 and TMR1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band 6 observations of main target lines H13CN(3-2), HC15N(3-2) in the two young stellar objects L1551 IRS 5 (IRAS 04287+1801) and TMR1 (IRAS 04361+2547). Bonus lines of HN13C(3-2) and a broad-band continuum window can be observed in addition at a reasonable data rate.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The sensitivity requirement is determined by the desired detection of the faintest line HC15N(3-2) at a S/N ratio of at least 10, as required for imaging. Based on H13CN(3-2) to H13CN(1-0) peak flux ratios in the range of 0.82-2.0 from the protostar sample by Jorgensen et al. 2004 (A&A 416, 603), the expected peak flux in the J=3-2 transition should be at least 0.8 times the peak flux of the J=1-0 transition. The estimates for HC15N(1-0) in L1551 IRS5 is 54 mJy/beam in a 1'' beam, so minimum expected peak flux for HC15N(3-2) is around 40mJy/beam in a 1'' beam. Thus, for a S/N ratio of 10, a sensitivity of 4 mJy/beam in 0.6 km/s channels is required.
For TMR1, we use the same approach: HC15N(1-0) has a peak flux of 50-65 mJy/beam, so the HC15N(3-2) flux should be at least 0.8*0.50 mJy/beam = 40-52 mJy/beam. For a S/N ratio of 10, a sensitivity of 4 mJy/beam in 0.6 km/s channels is required as well.
The continuum fluxes were taken from Hogerheijde et al. 1997, ApJ 489, 293 for L1527 and L1489.
The estimated line widths are expected to be similar to the J=1-0 transitions from Jorgensen et al. (2004, A&A 416, 603).

The requested spectral resolution of around 0.04 km/s for the spectral lines allows us resolve the line profiles (expected line widths of about 0.6-1 km/s). The spectra can be smoothed as required to reach the requested sensitivity.

We aim for a spatial resolution of about 1'', as this corresponds to solar system scales at the distance of Taurus (140 pc). At 1'' resolution, we will obtain several resolution elements across the protostellar envelopes. We do not aim at resolving the disks.
HCN(3-2) is expected to be more compact than HCN(1-0), which is extended by 10-20'' in L1527 (Choi et al. 1999, ApJS 122, 519) in barely resolved measurements with BIMA. The isotopologues are usually more compact and thus expected to be extended over an area of about 4-5''. We want to cover scales up to 10'' in case they are more extended than expected.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The isotopic composition of solar system matter is quite homogeneous, but large isotopic anomalies are found in volatiles like nitrogen. The terrestrial planets, meteorites, and comets are significantly enriched in 15-nitrogen compared to the Sun and Jupiter. Two processes have been proposed to explain the 15N-enrichment: chemical fractionation and isotope-selective photochemistry. Previous measurements of the 14N/15N ratio in star-forming regions were entirely based on single-dish data. They remained inconclusive about the relative importance of the two mechanisms because they cannot probe spatial signatures. We propose the first spatially resolved measurement of the 14N/15N ratio around four protostars to probe spatial variations in the 14N/15N ratio and tackle the question of what mechanism fractionates N-isotopes around protostars. Changes in the isotopic composition from the envelope to the disk scales can also be studied by comparing extended and compact components. The proposed observations will contribute to the understanding of N-isotope fractionation and the origin of the nitrogen isotope anomaly of the solar system.
